Ayssi comensan las paraulas de Albucasim .	Thus begin the words of Albucasis. (I'm assuming "Albucasim" is an alternative spelling or form of "Abulcasis," a famous Andalusian physician from the medieval period.)
O, filhs, pus yeu he a vos complit aquest libre, le qual es le derier de la sciencia de medicina, per le compliment de lu so consequit la fi en lu, e per las exposicios de lu, e per las declaracios de lu, es a mi vist que yeu complesca aquel a vos am aquest tractat, le qual es partida de la operacio am ma, so es cyrurgia.	O sons, since I have completed this book for you, which is the culmination of the medical science, with its conclusions, explanations, and clarifications, it seems to me that I have compiled this (book) for you along with this treatise, which is a part of the surgery branch of medicine, performed by hand.
Quar la operacio am ma es prostrada en nostre regio e en nostre temps de tot privada, entro que fort leu peric la sciencia de lu, e le vistigi de lu es ostat; e no romasero de lu sino alcunas petitas descripcios en les libres dels Antics, les quals mudero las mas e endevenc ad aquels error e heyssitacio entro que son clausas las entencios de lu e es elonguada la forsa de lu e l’art.	For manual operation is prohibited in our region and time, and the knowledge of it has become very rare, and only a few small descriptions remain in the books of the ancients, which have been altered and corrupted so that their intentions are concealed, and the strength and art of it have been weakened.
E es vist a mi que yeu vivifique aquela am ordenacio de aquest tractat en aquela segon la via de exposicio e de declaracio e de abreviacio; e per que vengua am las formas dels ferramentz de cautheri e dels autres instrumentz de la obra cum sia per addicio de la declaracio, e per preparacio de lu, la qual causa es necessaria.	And it seems to me that I should revive the method of this treatise through explanation, clarification, and abbreviation; and bring it with the forms of cautery instruments and other tools used in the work, along with additional explanations and preparations, which are necessary.
Mays la causa per la qual no es atrobat bo artifex am la sieua ma en aquest nostre temps, es quar la art de medicina es longua, e que cove le sieu actor denant aquo esser excercitat en la sciencia de anotomia la qual recontec Gualia entro que sapia les juvament dels membres e las formas de aquels, e la conjunctio e la separacio de lor; e haia la conoyssensa dels osses, dels nervis e dels lacertz, e·l nombre de aquels, e la egrecio de lor; e de las venas pulsatils e de las quietas, e dels locs del eyssiment de lor.	But the reason why no skilled craftsman is found with his hand in our time is that the art of medicine is extensive and requires its practitioner to be well-versed in the science of anatomy, which Galen describes as having knowledge of the limbs' assistance and forms, as well as their connection and separation. One must also have a understanding of bones, nerves, and tendons, along with their number and function, as well as the pulsating and non-pulsating veins, and the locations for their release.
E per aquo ditz Ypocras que am u nom es mot, mays en l’obra petit, e majorment en la art de la ma.	And for this reason, Hippocrates says that a name is significant, but in the work it amounts to little, and even less so in the art of manual operation. (This quote emphasizes the importance of practical knowledge and skill over just theoretical or book learning.)
Mays nos ja avem dit de aquel en l’introit de aquest libre; quar qui no es scient aquo que li avem dit de anotomia, no es evacuat que no caia en error per la qual siran mortz les homes, ayssi cum yeu he vist trops de aquels, quar alscus son formatz en esta sciencia e gettan se de aquela ses sciencia e ses experiment.	But we have already said this in the introduction of this book, for whoever is not knowledgeable about what we have said regarding anatomy is not likely to avoid error, and because of that, many people die. Thus, I have seen many who are mistaken in this science and lack knowledge and experience.
Quar yeu vi un metge folh e enperit aver incidit un apostema escrophilos en le colh de una femna, e incidic alcunas arterias del colh per que fluic gran sanc entro que la femna cazec morta entre las mas de lu.	For I saw a foolish and inexperienced doctor who attempted to lance an abscess on a woman's neck, cut some of her carotid arteries, causing massive bleeding, and the woman died in his hands. (This is a cautionary tale about the dangers of practicing medicine without proper knowledge and experience.)
E vi un autre metge que pres que el traguera una peyra d’un home le qual avia procesit en sa etat, e la peyra era gran, e venguet a lu e trayssec aquela peyra am un tros de la vesiqua, per que aquel home al tertz dia es mort.	And I saw another doctor who tried to remove a stone from a man's bladder while the patient was awake. The stone was large, and it came out along with a piece of his bladder. As a result, the man died three days later. (This is another cautionary tale about the risks of surgery.)
E yeu ja apelat fuy a estrayre aquela, e vi que per la grandesa de la peyra e per la disposicio del malaute conogui subre lu que morira.	And I had already advised against it and saw that due to the size of the stone and the patient's condition, I knew that he would not survive. (This is a further illustration of the importance of proper medical judgment.)
E vi un autre metge le qual prenia stipendic de un duc de nostra terra per cyrurgia, e endeven a un crastrat negre le qual era deves lu fractura en la coyssa de lu; e perparec le metge am la sua ignorancia, estrayssec la fractura, sobre la plagua, am pulvinas e astelas am forta strectura, e no layssec a la plagua espiracio.	And I saw another doctor who was paid by a duke in our land to perform surgery on a black castrated slave who had a fracture in his thigh. The ignorant doctor operated on the patient, setting the fracture with pillows and splints with excessive pressure, without allowing any ventilation of the wound. (This is an example of medical malpractice.)
E aprop le desliet segons los sieus desiriers, e aprop le relieg, e aprop le leyssec per alcus jorns e comandec que nos deslies le liament; e estec ayssi entro que la coyssa e·l pe foro apostematz, e pervenguet a perdicio.	And he bandaged him according to his own desires and left the wound unattended for several days, ordering that it not be opened or cared for. As a result, both the patient's thigh and foot became infected, leading to gangrene and ultimately death. (This is an example of medical neglect.)
E yeu fuy apelat a lu, e aparelhegui a desliar le liament, e conseguida es tranquilitat e enayssi amermet de sas dolors.	I was called to the patient and prepared to unbind the wound. Once I did so, the patient found relief from his pain and regained some composure. (This is an example of proper medical care.)
Mays empero ja corrupcio era confermada en le membre, per que no pogui refrenar aquela, e no cessec perambular la corrupcio en le membre entro que·l malaute peric.	However, the infection had already spread throughout the limb, and I could not stop it from spreading further. The patient's condition worsened as the infection continued to spread throughout his body. (This is an example of a severe medical emergency.)
E vi un autre metge le qual perforec un apostema cancros, e fo ulcerat aprop alscus dias, entro que foc magnificada la malicia de lu am lo senhor de lu.	And I saw another doctor who lanced a cancerous abscess and it became infected for several days, worsening the patient's condition significantly. (This is an example of improper medical treatment.)
La qual causa es quar le cranc caut es pur de humor melencolic, lahoras no cove que pervengua a lu am ferr de tot, sino que sia an membre le qual suffertes que de tot fos hostat.	The reason for this is that the cancerous growth is caused by black bile, and therefore should not be treated with cauterization in all cases, but rather in a location where it can coexist with the rest of the body. (This is an example of medical reasoning.)
E per aquo, filhs, necessari es a vos que la operacio am ma sia devisada en dos devesios: so es en operacio a lu qual es associada salut, e en obra am la qual es perilh en las majors disposicios.	Therefore, sons, it is necessary for you to distinguish between two types of manual operation: those associated with health and wellness, and those involving risk or danger in more complex cases. (This is an example of medical judgment.)
E yeu ja he exsitat aquo en tot loc de aquest libre en le qual venc opperacio en la qual es error e temor; per que necessari es a vos que guardetz aquo e layssetz aquel, per que les folhs no atrobo via a parlar e a vos desonestar.	I have already discussed in every part of this book the operation that involves error and fear; therefore, it is essential for you to be mindful of this and avoid it, so that you are not misled by false information or deception. (This is an example of medical caution.)
E donc prenetz las vostras armas am sollicitut e am proteccio de Dieu , e les vostres malautes am falicitat e am fermetat.	Therefore, take up your weapons (your medical skills) with diligence and under the protection of God, and approach your patients with ease and confidence. (This is an example of medical encouragement.)
E usatz de la milhor via per la gracia de Dieu perdusent a salut e a lausabla successio, e laysatz las malautias terriblas de difficil sanacio, e ostatz las vostras armas de aquo que vos fa temer, per so que ysitatio en vostra fe e en le vostre nom no vos evasisca: quar mays es remanent a la vostra gloria, e pus aut en le mon e en derier a las vostras sanctitatz.	And use the best method to bring about health and praiseworthy success through God's grace, and leave behind the terrible diseases that are difficult to cure. Set aside your fears and hesitations in your faith and name, for it is more glorious for you to remain steadfast, both now and forever, as a testament to your sanctity. (This is an example of medical advice and encouragement.)
Gualia ja diyssec en alcunas sieuas monicios:	Galen also said in some of his monitions:
“No mediquetz malautia mala, per so que mals metges no siatz nompnatz”.	"Do not treat a bad illness with poor medical skills, lest you be known as a bad doctor." (This is an example of medical ethics.)
E yeu ja he devesit aquest libre segontz tres capitols.	I have divided this book into three chapters. (This statement could be used to conclude the introduction or preface to the book, and signal that the author is about to begin the main text.)
Comensa la divisio del libre, e primier de la primieyra partida.	Here begins the division of the book, starting with the first section. (This statement indicates that the author is beginning the main body of the work, and signaling the start of a new subsection or chapter.)
Le primier capitol ordenat del cap entro·s pes, en las formas dels instrumentz e en les ferrementz dels cauteris, e de aquo que necessari es en la opperacio.	The first chapter is dedicated to the head and feet, including the forms of surgical instruments and cautery tools, as well as what is necessary for the operation. La divisio de la segonda partida.	The division of the second section. (This statement indicates that the author is beginning a new subsection or chapter.)
Le segon capitol, de siccio e perforacio, e de ventosas, e de plaguas, e de extractio de sagetas e de semblantz ad aquelas, tot capitolat e ordenat de las formas dels instrumentz.	The second chapter is dedicated to dryness and penetration, including the use of cupping glasses, treatment of abscesses, and removal of arrows and similar objects, with a focus on the forms and uses of surgical instruments. Divisio de la tersa partida.	The division of the third section. (This statement indicates that the author is beginning a new subsection or chapter.) [* La tercia capitol, del esplanchs e de l’estomach, e dels intestins e del fetge e del pancreas e del ronyon e del spleyn e de la vesica e del testiculum e del penis e de la matrice e del ventre e de le mamelles e dels orificis del cors, e de aquo que necessari es en la opperacio.

De cauteri am foc e am medicina aguda e rememoracio de la opperacio.	On cauterization with fire and sharp medicine, as well as a reminder about surgical operations. (This statement indicates that the author is beginning a new subsection or chapter and provides a brief overview of what will be covered in this section.)
Am aquel comensa le tractat de tot le libre.	With this begins the treatise for the entire book. (This statement signals that the author is beginning the main body of the work, and may indicate that the following material covers the most important or fundamental concepts in the text.)
Cove que yeu digua la qualitat dels juvamentz de aquel cauteri e dels noccumentz de lu, e en qual compleccio sia prohibit cauteri.	It is necessary for me to discuss the benefits and drawbacks of using cautery, as well as the situations in which it should be avoided. (This statement signals that the author will provide important information about a specific medical technique or treatment.) [* La qualitat dels juvamentz de aquel cauteri es que el foc le dona calor e la sequedat, lo qual es bo per los humors melencolic e freds e viscos. E la causa es quar le flama del fuego entra en lu, laqual cove que sia forta, e esparcsec por aquel cauteri e lei sient lo membre al qual es applicat a la sua sequedat e a sa calor; e per aquo se dissipa los humors melencolic e freds e viscos.
Donc dic que·l sermo de la qualitat del juvament de cauteri e del noccument de lu es sermo lonc e prolixs, e subtil per sciensa, e secret amaguat; e ja de lu a parlat gran multitut de savis, e de lu se son desacordatz, et a mi abasta un petit dels sermons de lor, temen perlonguacio.	Therefore I say that the discussion about the benefits and drawbacks of cautery is lengthy and complex, requiring extensive knowledge and understanding. Many wise people have spoken at length on this topic, and there are many differing opinions. I can only provide a brief summary of their teachings, as I do not wish to prolong this discourse. (This statement shows the author's humility and recognition that they cannot possibly cover all aspects of the topic in depth.)
E donc dic que cauteri comfereys a tota compleccio universalment la qual es am materia o ses materia, exceptat dos compleccios, las quals son compleccios caudas ses materia .	Therefore I say that cautery is beneficial in most universal cases, whether with or without matter, with two exceptions. These are the "cauda sine materia" conditions, which do not respond well to cauterization. (This statement signals that the author will now discuss specific medical conditions where cautery should be avoided.)
En la compleccio cauda e secca am materia se desecordero; quar alcus dyssero que cauteri es juvatiu ad aquela, e les autres dyssero le contrari de aquel, que cauteri no es convenient en malautia la qual es per qualiditat e per siccitat, quar natura del foc es qualiditat e siccitat, e enconvenient es que malautia cauda e secca am aquo que es caut e sec sia sanada.	In the "cauda sine materia" condition of dryness and hardness with matter, there is disagreement among physicians. Some say that cautery is beneficial in this case, while others argue against it. Those who argue against it do so because the nature of fire is heat and dryness, which would be counterproductive in a condition already characterized by these qualities. (This statement shows that medical knowledge and practice can vary widely, even among experts.)
E diysec aquel que ditz le contrari de aquel, que per cauteri es fayt juvament en tota malautia cauda e secca que ve en les cors dels homes, quar quan tu comparas le cors de home e las humiditatz de lu a la compleccio del foc, atrobas le cors de home freg.	The author also mentions that some argue against the use of cautery in dry and hard conditions, stating that it is not beneficial because the human body is naturally moist and cool compared to fire. However, this argument does not take into account the specific qualities of each individual condition, which may require different treatments. (This statement shows that medical knowledge is complex and multifaceted, requiring careful consideration of many factors in order to make an accurate diagnosis and treatment plan.)
E yeu dic per le sermo de aquel, que esperiment aquo ja a mi alscunas vetz a descubert.	And I say from experience that I have observed this myself on several occasions. (This statement signals that the author has personal knowledge and expertise in the field of medicine, and has seen the effects of different treatments firsthand.) [* E diysec alcus metges que cauteri es juvament en tota malautia cauda e secca, per so que aquesta compleccio no sia fort e prolongat.
Mays empero no cove que vengua sobre aquo aquel que ja es exproat e excersitat en le capitol de cauteri per derier exercici, e a conogut la diversitat de la compleccio dels homes e la disposicio de las malautias en lor meteyssas, e las causas de aquelas, e·ls accidentz de lor, e l’espasi del temps de aquelas.	However, it is not necessary for those who are experienced and trained in the chapter on cautery to rehash what has already been discussed, as they have likely encountered a wide variety of human conditions and illnesses, and understand their causes and effects, as well as the timing and circumstances involved. (This statement recognizes the expertise and experience of medical professionals, who must be able to make quick decisions based on their knowledge and judgment.)
Mays en las autras compleccios, no es sobre vos temor, e majorment en las malautias fregas e humidas, quar ja totz les metges se son acordatz sobre aquels, e no so desecordatz en le juvament am cauteri en aquelas.	However, in other conditions, there is no reason to be afraid to use cautery, especially in cases of cold and wet illnesses, where all doctors agree that it can be helpful. (This statement reinforces the idea that medical knowledge and practice are complex, but also recognize that there are some general principles and agreements among medical experts.)
E sapiatz, filhs, que del secret de curacio per cauteri am foc e de la bontat de lu, so sobre cauteri am medicina comburent, es quar le foc es simple, la accio del qual no perven sino al membre le qual es cauterizat e no notz al autre membre am lu ajustat sino am petit nocument.	And know, sons, that the secret of healing through cautery with fire and the benefits of it come from cautery with burning medicine, because fire has a simple action that only affects the area that is cauterized, and does not harm other nearby areas. (This statement emphasizes the importance of using caution when performing medical procedures, and recognizes that some treatments have limited effects.) [* La medicina comburent es aquela que sia composta de diversas substancias aqueleas e igneas, le quals son combinatas am un foc moderat.
Mays la accio de medicina comburent perven ad aquel en les membres le qual de lu alunhat, e fort leu fa venir en le membre malautia de dificil sanacio e fort leu ausit.	The action of fiery medicine reaches the members of the one who is far away, and quickly brings to the diseased member difficulty in healing and makes it easily inflamed.
Mays le foc, per la sua sublimitat e de la sua substancia bontat, no fa aquo sino que superfluisca E ja es a nos conogut per experiment e per longitut de servitut de studi am l’art sobre le veritat de las causas; e per aquo yeu so excusat de la longitut del sermo E si no fos que no es legut al mieu libre en aquest pausero a vos secret amaguat am le foc, e la qualitat de la operacio de lu en les cors e de la sieua expulcio per la qual expellis las malautias, am sermo philosophic demostratiu, le qual siria acuit en las vostras pessas.	But fire, due to its elevated nature and the goodness of its substance, does not do anything but bring about superfluity. And this is already known to us through experience and length of service in the art on the truth of causes; and for that reason I am excused from the length of speech. And if it were not prohibited in my book to reveal to you here the hidden secret of fire, and its operation's quality in bodies, as well as its expulsion through which illnesses are expelled, demonstrated with philosophical language, it would be fitting to arouse your interest.
E sapiatz, filhs, que els se desacordan del temps en le qual es convenient far cauteri e pausan le milhor temps de primaveyra.	And know, son, that they disagree on the time which is appropriate for making a cautery and choose the best time of spring.
E yeu dic que cauteri es convenient en tot temps, per so que le nocument per le temps accident es submergit en le juvament de aquo que am le cauteri es atirat, e majorment si le cauteri es per dolors o de dolors necessaries, fortz e fistinas, las quals no suffertan tarditat per so que es temut de aquelas que vengua malicia, que es major que petit nocument entrant per lo temps.	And I say that cautery is appropriate in all times, because the harm caused by the accidental time is submerged in the benefit of what is attracted with cautery, and especially if the cautery is for necessary pains or painful necessities, strong and intense, which do not tolerate delay, due to fear of those who bring malice, which is greater than any small harm that may enter through the time.
E aysso no catz en vostras pessas, o, filhs, aquo no estiman sino le poble vulguar e les fols metges, so es que ad aquela malautia que es sanada per cauteri no es redicio tot temps, e pausan aquel consequen.	And this should not concern you, my son, for only the common people and foolish doctors think this way, that is, to reduce a disease which can be healed by cautery, one must not always use it, but rather choose the appropriate time.
E la causa no es ges ayssi quo els cuydan per aquo, quar cauteri no es sino en loc de medicina la qual altera la compleccio e esicca las humiditatz las quals son causa per que veno las dolors.	And the reason is not as they believe, because cautery is nothing but a substitute for medicine which alters the complexion and dries up the humidity which are the cause of pain.
Mays empero cauteri superflueys sobre la medicina per volicitat de la sua valitut e vertut de la sua operacio e grandesa del sieu senhor.	However, cautery is excessive over medicine due to the eagerness of its effectiveness, virtue of its operation, and greatness of its power.
E es possible que la sua malautia retorne en alcuna hora del temps, segon la compleccio del malaute e la locacio de la sua malautia, e la vertut de lu, e aquo que es preparat en le cors de lu de la agreguacio de las superfluitatz en lu, e aquo que es pervengut a lu en la sua acquisicio en viandas e semblantz de aquelas causas; sino que la malautia en la qual sia aministrat cauteri sia malautia subtil en membre de paucas superfluitatz e humiditatz, ayssi cum cauteri de dent per dolor e semblantz ad aquel, possible es que en lu no retorne aquela dolor, mays aquo se fa en petitz.	And it is possible that the illness may return in some hour of time, according to the complexion of the patient and the location of their illness, as well as its virtue, and what has been prepared in their body from the accumulation of excesses in them, and what has come upon them in the acquisition of food and similar causes; unless the illness in which cautery is administered is a subtle illness in a member with few superfluities and humors, such as dental cautery for pain or similar, it is possible that the pain will not return, but only slightly.
E mays sermo vulgar es que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina, e es sermo dreyturier, no ad aquo que els entendo en lu, quar els crezo que no es curacio que aprofieyta am medicina ni am autra causa aprop cauteri.	And the common saying is that cautery is the last resort of medicine, and it is a correct statement, not in the way that I understand it, because I do not believe that there is any healing with medicine or any other cause apart from cautery.
E la causa es en contrari de aquo; e la entencio que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina no es sino quan administram las manieyras de curacio en alcunas malautias, e aquelas medicinas no conferieysso, e aprop en la fi de la causa aministra hom cauteri, e aprofieyta ad aquela.	And the reason is the opposite of that; and the intention that cautery is the last resort of medicine does not mean that when we administer methods of healing for some diseases, and those medicines are not effective, then at the end of the cause, one resorts to cautery, which is successful.
E lahoras de aqui cat16 que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina, no segon la entencio la qual entendo les vulgars e trops dels fols metges.	And so from here it is clear that cautery is the last resort of medicine, but not in the way that the common people and foolish doctors understand it.
E diyssero les antics que cauteri am aur es milhor que cauteri am ferr, e no diyssero aquo sino per la equalitat del aur e sublimitat de la sua sustancia.	And the ancients said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron, and they did not say this without reason, but rather because of the equality of gold and the loftiness of its substance.
E diyssero que le loc de cauteri no fa brac, cum aquo no sia absolutament vertat, quar yeu ja he aquo proat e he atrobat que aquel no fa aquo sino en alcus cors ses les autres, e cauteri am aquel es bo e milhor que am ferr ayssi quo els diyssero; mays empero quan tu fas cauteri am foc am de aur, no es a tu declarat, quar es egnit segon la quantitat que tu vols per la rugor de l’aur, e quar prepara a recebre freg; e si ajustas sobre lu ignicio se fon l’aur per le foc, e caso en le foc alcunas laminas per que le artifex catz per la occupacio de aquel.	And they said that the location of cautery does not matter, but this is not absolutely true, as I have proven and discovered that it only works in some bodies without others, and cauterization with this is good and better than iron as they said; but when you perform cautery with fire and gold, it is not so simple, because the gold ignites according to the amount of heat you want due to its brightness, and it prepares to receive the treatment; and if you place a flame on top of it, the gold will melt in the fire, and some layers will be burnt due to the intensity of the craftsman's work.
E per aquo es fayt cauteri am ferr deves nos pus leugerament e pus propdanament a rectitut de operacio.	And therefore, cautery is performed with iron more lightly and more directly according to the operation.
E yeu ja he ordenat aquest capitol en le cauteri segon capitols, et he ordenat aquels del cap entro les pes, per so que aleugo le demandant aquo que vol de lu.	And I have already organized this chapter on cautery according to chapters, and I have organized those of the head down to the feet, in order to lighten the request for it.
De cauteri de dolor de cap per frigiditat e humiditat.	Of cautery for pain in the head due to coldness and dampness.
Le capitol primier.	The first chapter.
Aquesta cauterizacio confereys a la humiditat e frigiditat sobre le servel accident de la qual so doas causas, so es causa de soda e multitut de flux raumatic, apelat corissa, del cap a las partidas dels huelhs e de las aurelhas fluent, e multitut de dormir, e de dolor de dentz e del guolayro, e universalment de tota malautia que ve per fregiditat, ayssi cum paraliticament, sodo e apoplexio, e semblantz en aquelas malautias.	This cauterization is beneficial for dampness and coldness due to the secondary cause of which there are two causes: firstly, headaches and a large amount of running fluid from the ears and eyes, excessive sleepiness, toothache, and gum pain, and generally all illnesses caused by coldness, such as paralysis, sudden pain, apoplexy, and similar symptoms in those illnesses.
La forma de aquesta cauterizacio es aquesta, que primieyrament comandes al malaute que sia evacuat am medicina lacsativa le cap mondificant, per tres o per quatre nueytz, segon que exhigeys la vertut del malaute e la edat de lu e la sua costuma.	The method of this cauterization is as follows: firstly, you should instruct the patient to be purged with a laxative medicine that cleanses the head for three or four nights, depending on the strength of the illness, age, and habits of the patient.
E aprop comanda li que raza le sieu cap am razor, e aprop fay aquel sezer entre las tuas mas sobre una banca cayrada e que pause las suas mas sobre le pietz sieu.	And then you should command them to shave their head with a razor, and then you should make the incision between your hands on a tilted bench, while they place their hands on their own chest.
E aprop pausa la razit de la tua palma aprop le pous sobre la razit del nas entre les huels sieus.	And then place the blade of your palm over the wound on the bridge of the nose between their ears.
Mays empero, cum le tieu dit del mieg loc es pervengut, signa aquel loc am tenta, e aprop igneys le cauteri olivar del qual aquesta es la forma:	However, when the desired location has been reached, mark that spot with ink, and then heat up the olive-shaped cautery tool, which looks like this:

E estiman de aquel loc expiran la vapors del cap.	And they consider that from this location, the vapors of the head escape.

Mays a mi no so vistas aquestas doas specias de cauteri de tot, sino en alcus homes segon via de temor; e layssa aquel, deves mi, milhor es am salut, quan es; quar le cap es develitat per solucio de continuitat de lu ayssi cum havem testificat en les autres membres, e majorment quan le cap del malaute es de freul natura. De cauterisacio de dolor de dent.	Chapter 21: On Cauterization for Tooth Pain.
Quan dolor de dent es per fregiditat, o en lu es freg o verm, o no comfereys la curacio am medicina, lahoras cauteri en aquela es segon dos manieyras: o cauteri am boder de vacas, o cauteri am foc. Cauterization with a cow's horn involves taking a horn from a cow and heating it in the fire until it becomes red-hot. Then take a piece of cloth, wrap it around the end of the probe, and quickly place the heated horn over the painful tooth until it cools down.
E aprop itera aquela alcunas veguadas entro que la vertut del foc pervengua a la razit de la dentz.	And repeat this several times until the heat of the cautery reaches the root of the tooth. The purpose is to ensure that the heat penetrates deeply into the tooth and alleviates any pain or discomfort caused by cold or moisture. By repeating the process several times, you can help to ensure that the treatment is effective and long-lasting.

This method is recommended when there is decay or infection in the tooth that needs to be removed. The heat from the cautery can help to kill any bacteria and promote healing. It's important to ensure that the cautery reaches the base of the cavity, as this is where the infection is likely to be located.
